facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 61 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEAL No. 61 OF 1964 Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 28, 1963 of the. Gujarat High Court

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated October 28, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 697 of 1962

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 28, 1963 of the. Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 697 of 1962.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 28, 1964

anchor.surface_text: April 28, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-This appeal, by special leave, is directed against the order of the Bombay High Court

facts.text: Appellant is a tenant of the ground-floor of a house owned by the respondent

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading to the appeal, in short, are that the appellant is a tenant of the ground-floor of a house owned by the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent sued for ejectment of appellant requiring entire house for residential purpose

anchor.surface_text: The respondent sued for the ejectment of the appellant on the ground that he required the entire house, including the portion occupied by the appellant, for his residential purpose.

facts.text: Suit bungalow is very old, built about 75 years ago

anchor.surface_text: He further stated in the plaint-. The whole suit bungalow is very old-built about 75 years ago and at present its different parts are likely to give way and companylapse.

facts.text: A little portion of an upper balcony had collapsed before sometime

anchor.surface_text: Before sometime, a little portion of an upper balcony had companylapsed. In the circumstances, on find- ing it unsafe to stay in it without making additions, alterations and necessary changes,

facts.text: Respondent has got the upper portion of the suit bungalow vacated

anchor.surface_text: 1. the plaintiff, have got the upper portion of the said suit bungalow vacated at present and only after the whole bungalow is got overhauled as -stated in para above,

facts.text: Appellant contested the suit including that respondent did not reasonably and bona fide require premises for occupation

anchor.surface_text: Me appellant companytested the suit on various grounds including the ones that the respondent did number reasonably and bona fide require the premises for his occupation and that he did number reasonably and bona fide require the premises for carrying out repairs.

facts.text: Trial Court found that respondent bona fide required premises for occupation and decreed ejectment

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court found that the respondent bona fide required the premises for his occupation. It repelled the companytention of the appellant that the provisions of s. 1 3   I   g  would number be applicable

facts.text: Trial court repelled contention that s.13(1)(g) not applicable if landlord intends major repairs

anchor.surface_text: It repelled the companytention of the appellant that the provisions of s. 1 3   I   g  would number be applicable when the landlord did number wish to occupy the premises as such but intended to occupy it after carrying out major repairs. and decreed the respondents suit for ejectment.

facts.text: Defendant's appeal to appellate court was dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The defendant went up in appeal. It was dismissed. The appellate Court, agreed with the views of the trial Court.

facts.text: Revision petition to High Court was rejected

anchor.surface_text: The defendant then presented a revision petition to the High Court. It was rejected.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld preliminary objection that revision to High Court was incompetent

anchor.surface_text: We uphold the preliminary objection and hold that the revision was incompetent. The question raised was whether a decree in ejectment should be passed on the ground of personal requirement under s. 1 3  1   g

facts.text: Courts below found that respondent bona fide required premises for occupation

anchor.surface_text: The respondent alleged, and the Courts below have found, that he bona fide required the premises in the suit for occupation by himself.

facts.text: Respondent stated he would take up residence after overhauling premises

anchor.surface_text: The respondent stated in the plaint that he would take up residence in the pre- mises after overhauling it.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees case falls under cl. g of s.13(1) not cl. hh

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the Courts below that the respondents case falls under cl.  g  when he bona fiede requires the premises for his own occupation.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the respondents case came within cl.  g  of sub-s.  1  of s. 13 of the Act and therefore dismiss the appeal with companyts.

facts.text: Trial Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from this section that the trial Court had full jurisdiction to entertain the suit for ejectment. That being so, it had jurisdiction to interpret whether cl.  g  of s. 13 1  would apply

facts.text: Appellate Court agreed with trial Court views

anchor.surface_text: The appellate Court, agreed with the views of the trial Court. The defendant then presented a revision petition to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court could not interfere in revision with appellate Court decision

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyld number, therefore, interfere in revision with the decision of the appellate Court, even if it had gone wrong, on facts or law, in the exercise of its jurisdiction.

issues.text: whether a decree in ejectment should be passed on the ground of personal requirement under s. 13(1)(g) of the Act where it was proved that the landlord wanted to pull down the premises and build another and then occupy it

anchor.surface_text: The question raised was whether a decree in ejectment should be passed on the ground of personal requirement under s. 1 3  1   g  of the Act where it was proved that the landlord wanted to pull down the premises and build another and then occupy it. It was said that in such a case he had to proceed under cl.  hh  of s. 13 1 .

issues.text: whether the respondents case came within the provisions of s. 13(1)(g) of the Act or fell within the provisions of s. 13(1)(hh)

anchor.surface_text: The sole question to determine in this appeal is whether the respondents case came within the provisions of s. 13  1   g  of the Act or fell within the provisions of s. 13  1   hh . We may number set out these provisions 13 1  Nothwithstanding anything companytained in this Act but subject to the provisions of section 15

issues.text: whether cl. g will apply only when the landlord bona fide needs to occupy the premises without making any alteration in them

anchor.surface_text: We do number therefore agree with the companytention that cl.  g  will apply only when the landlord bona fide needs to occupy the premises without making any alteration in them, i.e., to occupy the identical building which the tenant occupies.

holdings.text: We uphold the preliminary objection and hold that the revision was incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: companypet- ent. We uphold the preliminary objection and hold that the revision was incompetent. The question raised was whether a decree in ejectment should be passed on the ground of personal requirement under s. 1 3  1   g

holdings.reasoning_summary: No question of jurisdiction involved; trial court had authority under s.28 to interpret s.13(1)(g); High Court revision limited to jurisdictional errors.

holdings.text: It is clear from this section that the trial Court had full jurisdiction to entertain the suit for ejectment. That being so, it had jurisdiction to interpret whether cl. g of s. 13 1 would apply

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 of the Act gives jurisdiction to the Court specified in it, to try a suit or proceeding, between a landlord and tenant relating to possession of the premises. That section expressely provides that numberother Court, subject to the provisions of sub-s.  2  which do number apply to this case, has jurisdiction to entertain such suits. It is clear from this section that the trial Court had full jurisdiction to entertain the suit for ejectment. That being so, it had jurisdiction to interpret whether cl.  g  of s. 13 1  would apply

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.28 vests exclusive jurisdiction in trial court for ejectment suits including interpretation of s.13(1)(g).

holdings.text: The High Court could not, therefore, interfere in revision with the decision of the appellate Court, even if it had gone wrong, on facts or law, in the exercise of its jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate Court had jurisdiction to hear the appeal. The High Court could number, therefore, interfere in revision with the decision of the appellate Court, even if it had gone wrong, on facts or law, in the exercise of its jurisdiction. It follows that the revision application had to be dismissed by the High Court and that this appeal too must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revisional jurisdiction limited; no jurisdictional error by lower courts.

holdings.text: We agree with the Courts below that the respondents case falls under cl. g when he bona fiede requires the premises for his own occupation.

anchor.surface_text: We need number express an opinion on this point, as, for reasons to be mentioned later, the case falls under cl.  g  and number under cl.  hh  of s. 13  I  of the Act. We agree with the Courts below that the respondents case falls under cl.  g  when he bona fiede requires the premises for his own occupation. The mere fact that he intends to make alterations in the house either on account of his sweet will or on account of absolute necessity in view of the companydition of the house, does number affect the question of his requiring the house bona fide and reasonably for his oc- cupation, when he has proved his need for occupying the house.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bona fide personal requirement proved; overhaul/alterations do not shift to cl. hh.

holdings.text: There is no such prohibition either in the language of cl. g or in any other provision of the Act to the effect that the landlord must occupy the house for residence without making any alterations in it.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that he intends to make alterations in the house either on account of his sweet will or on account of absolute necessity in view of the companydition of the house, does number affect the question of his requiring the house bona fide and reasonably for his oc- cupation, when he has proved his need for occupying the house. There is numbersuch prohibition either in the language of cl.  g  or in any other provision of the Act to the effect that the landlord must occupy the house for residence without making any alterations in it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading; no added restriction; ordinary meaning of 'occupy' and 'premises'.

holdings.text: We do not therefore agree with the contention that cl. g will apply only when the landlord bona fide needs to occupy the premises without making any alteration in them, i.e., to occupy the identical building which the tenant occupies.

anchor.surface_text: There is therefore numberreason why restrictions number mentioned in the grounds be read into them. We do number therefore agree with the companytention that cl.  g  will apply only when the landlord bona fide needs to occupy the premises without making any alteration in them, i.e., to occupy the identical building which the tenant occupies. There is numberjustification to give such a narrow companystruction either to the word premises or to the word occupies which have been companystrued by this Court in Krishanual Ishwarlal Desai v. Rai Vijkor 1  referred to later.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects narrow construction; follows precedent on 'occupy'; no logical basis for prohibition.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that once the landlord establishes that he bona fide requires the premises for his occupation he is entitled to recover possession of it from the tenant in view of the provisions of sub-cl. g of s. 13 1 irrespective of the fact whether he would occupy the premises without making any alterations to them or after making the necessary alterations.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that once the landlord esta- blishes that he bona fide requires the premises for his occupation. he is entitled to recover possession of it from the tenant in view of the provisions of sub-cl.  g  of s. 13 1  irrespective of the fact whether he would occupy the premises without making any alterations to them or after making the necessary alterations. The provisions of cl.  hh  cannot possibly apply to the case where a landlord reasonably and bona fide requires the premises for his own occupation even if

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies cl.g broadly; alterations irrelevant to bona fide need; protects tenant via s.17.

holdings.text: The provisions of cl. hh cannot possibly apply to the case where a landlord reasonably and bona fide requires the premises for his own occupation even if he had to demolish the premises and to erect a new building on them.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of cl.  hh  cannot possibly apply to the case where a landlord reasonably and bona fide requires the premises for his own occupation even if he had to demolish the premises and to erect a new building on them. The provisions of cl.  hh  apply to cases where the landlord does number require the premises for his own occupation but requires them for erecting a new building which is to be let out to tenants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl. hh requires undertakings for new building to double tenements for letting; distinct from personal occupation.

holdings.text: We therefore hold that the respondents case came within cl. g of sub-s. 1 of s. 13 of the Act and therefore dismiss the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In a case like the present, if the plaintiffs on getting possession start their work of demolition within the prescribed period, they would have occupied the premises in order to erect a building fit for their occupation. We therefore hold that the respondents case came within cl.  g  of sub-s.  1  of s. 13 of the Act and therefore dismiss the appeal with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies holdings to facts; affirms lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 of the Act gives jurisdiction to the Court specified in it, to try a suit or proceeding, between a landlord and tenant relating to possession of the premises. That section expressely provides that numberother Court, subject to the provisions of sub-s.  2  which do number apply to this case, has jurisdiction to entertain such suits. It is clear from this section that the trial Court had full jurisdiction to entertain the suit for ejectment. That being so, it had jurisdiction to interpret whether cl.  g  of s. 13 1  would apply
We therefore hold that the respondents case came within cl. g of sub-s. 1 of s. 13 of the Act and therefore dismiss the appeal with costs.
in such a case he had to proceed under cl.  hh  of s. 13 1 . It is clear that the question so raised is one of interpretation o

edges.explanation: Holding h3 applies and grounds the concept c13 by stating non-interference principle

anchor.surface_text: The appellate Court had jurisdiction to hear the appeal. The High Court could number, therefore, interfere in revision with the decision of the appellate Court, even if it had gone wrong, on facts or law, in the exercise of its jurisdiction. It follows that the revision application had to be dismissed by the High Court and that this appeal too must fail.
We therefore hold that the respondents case came within cl. g of sub-s. 1 of s. 13 of the Act and therefore dismiss the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We need number express an opinion on this point, as, for reasons to be mentioned later, the case falls under cl.  g  and number under cl.  hh  of s. 13  I  of the Act. We agree with the Courts below that the respondents case falls under cl.  g  when he bona fiede requires the premises for his own occupation. The mere fact that he intends to make alterations in the house either on account of his sweet will or on account of absolute necessity in view of the companydition of the house, does number affect the question of his requiring the house bona fide and reasonably for his oc- cupation, when he has proved his need for occupying the house.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that he intends to make alterations in the house either on account of his sweet will or on account of absolute necessity in view of the companydition of the house, does number affect the question of his requiring the house bona fide and reasonably for his oc- cupation, when he has proved his need for occupying the house. There is numbersuch prohibition either in the language of cl.  g  or in any other provision of the Act to the effect that the landlord must occupy the house for residence without making any alterations in it.
We therefore hold that the respondents case came within cl. g of sub-s. 1 of s. 13 of the Act and therefore dismiss the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: There is therefore numberreason why restrictions number mentioned in the grounds be read into them. We do number therefore agree with the companytention that cl.  g  will apply only when the landlord bona fide needs to occupy the premises without making any alteration in them, i.e., to occupy the identical building which the tenant occupies. There is numberjustification to give such a narrow companystruction either to the word premises or to the word occupies which have been companystrued by this Court in Krishanual Ishwarlal Desai v. Rai Vijkor 1  referred to later.
We therefore hold that the respondents case came within cl. g of sub-s. 1 of s. 13 of the Act and therefore dismiss the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that once the landlord esta- blishes that he bona fide requires the premises for his occupation. he is entitled to recover possession of it from the tenant in view of the provisions of sub-cl.  g  of s. 13 1  irrespective of the fact whether he would occupy the premises without making any alterations to them or after making the necessary alterations. The provisions of cl.  hh  cannot possibly apply to the case where a landlord reasonably and bona fide requires the premises for his own occupation even if

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of cl.  hh  cannot possibly apply to the case where a landlord reasonably and bona fide requires the premises for his own occupation even if he had to demolish the premises and to erect a new building on them. The provisions of cl.  hh  apply to cases where the landlord does number require the premises for his own occupation but requires them for erecting a new building which is to be let out to tenants.

anchor.surface_text: In a case like the present, if the plaintiffs on getting possession start their work of demolition within the prescribed period, they would have occupied the premises in order to erect a building fit for their occupation.
